bestBHT.bht: We know that the law is spiritual, sprung from God, who is a Spirit, and requiring of men spiritual purity. However, I am carnal, subject to the law of the flesh and in bondage to it. In this state, sin dominates the unrenewed man, making him a slave, completely sold under sin. While the law demands spiritual obedience, I, as a fleshly creature, am incapable of yielding such obedience. I am in a permanent state of slavery to sin, which controls my mind, heart, and actions.

Henry Alford: We know (it is an acknowledged principle amongst us) that the law is spiritual (sprung from God, who is a Spirit, and requiring of men spiritual purity.
I am carnal (subject to the law of the flesh, and in bondage to it.
The 'I' appears here in its totality as sinful, while in vv. 16, 20 it is distinguished from sin.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For we know that the law is spiritual—in its demands.
but I am carnal—fleshly, and as such, incapable of yielding spiritual obedience.
Albert Barnes: It is what will strike plain people as being the natural meaning; people who do not have a theory to support, and who understand language in its usual sense.
Because the expressions which occur are such as cannot be understood of an impenitent sinner.
This is the natural and obvious construction, and if this be not the meaning, it is impossible to account for his having changed the past tense Romans 7:7 to the present.
Marvin Vincent: This unspiritual, material, phenomenal nature" so dominates the unrenewed man that he is described as consisting of flesh.
Spiritual [πνευματικος] . The expression of the Holy Spirit.
Sold under sin. As a slave.
John Calvin: The law requires a celestial and an angelic righteousness, in which no spot is to appear, to whose clearness nothing is to be wanting: but I am a carnal man, who can do nothing but oppose it.
We are so entirely controlled by the power of sin, that the whole mind, the whole heart, and all our actions are under its influence.

We sin spontaneously, as it would be no sin, were it not voluntary. But we are so given up to sin, that we can do willingly nothing but sin; for the corruption which bears rule within us thus drives us onward.
Philip Schaff: The law is spiritual; in its essence it is divine, because its characteristics are those of the Holy Spirit.
We think Paul here describes himself not as a Christian, but over against the law.
A permanent state of slavery is referred to; sin being personified as the master.
Archibald T. Robertson: Spiritual (πνευματικος). Spirit-caused and spirit-given and like the Holy Spirit."
But I am carnal (εγω δε σαρκινος ειμ). 'Fleshen' as in 1 Corinthians 3:1 which see, more emphatic even than σαρκικος,' a creature of flesh.'
Sold under sin (πεπραμενος υπο την αμαρτιαν). Perfect passive participle of πιπρασκω, old verb, to sell. Sin has closed the mortgage and owns its slave.
John Gill: We who have a spiritual understanding of the law, who have been led into the true nature of it by the Spirit of God, know by experience that that itself is 'spiritual'...
The law may be said to be 'spiritual,' because it comes from the Spirit of God; and reaches to the spirit of man; it requires truth in the inward parts; spiritual service and obedience...
To this spirituality of the law the apostle opposes himself, but I am carnal, sold under sin...
John Wesley: Totally enslaved; slaves bought with money were absolutely at their master's disposal.

bhtAttempts.bht: We know that the law is spiritual, requiring spiritual purity. However, I am carnal and in bondage to the law of the flesh. In this verse, the 'I' represents the sinful nature which dominates the unrenewed man, making him a slave to sin. Sin has closed the mortgage and owns its slave. Although the law is spiritual, reaching to the spirit of man and requiring obedience, I am completely enslaved, sold under sin. As a carnal man, I can do nothing but oppose the celestial righteousness that the law demands. I am controlled by the power of sin, with my whole mind, heart, and actions under its influence.

We know that the law is spiritual, requiring spiritual purity. However, I am carnal and in bondage to the law of the flesh. In this [state], the 'I' represents the sinful nature which dominates the unrenewed man, making him a slave to sin. Sin has closed the mortgage and owns its slave. Although the law is spiritual, reaching to the spirit of man and requiring obedience, I am completely enslaved, sold under sin. As a carnal man, I can do nothing but oppose the celestial righteousness that the law demands.

We know that the law is spiritual, sprung from God, who is a Spirit, and requiring of men spiritual purity. However, I am carnal, subject to the law of the flesh and in bondage to it. In this state, sin dominates the unrenewed man, making him a slave, completely sold under sin. While the law demands spiritual obedience, I, as a fleshly creature, am incapable of yielding such obedience. I am in a permanent state of slavery to sin, which controls my mind, heart, and actions.

The law, originating from the Spirit of God, requires spiritual purity and obedience. Meanwhile, I find myself carnal, enslaved to the law of the flesh. I am completely sold under sin, subject to its control in every aspect of my being. Despite the spiritual nature of the law, I, as a fleshly individual, am unable to meet its demands. Sin holds me in a state of bondage, overpowering my thoughts, desires, and actions. I am a slave to sin, unable to break free on my own.

We acknowledge that the law is spiritual, emanating from God who is a Spirit, and requiring spiritual purity. However, I am in a carnal state, subject to the law of the flesh and held in bondage to it. This unrenewed nature dominated by sin sells me as its slave. Even though the law demands spiritual obedience, I, as a fleshly being, am unable to comply. I am completely enslaved to sin, with my mind, heart, and actions under its authority.
